column18: Provide any additional comments that you feel that were not addressed by the above items or that you wish to expand upon here.

column15: I think the resources are helpful because R is very new to me and I have tried to max them out in learning.
column16: I think I would try to match the learning check with what we are doing in class because especially being a new learner, I feel Im spending a lot of time looking up information trying to match my understanding to the questions being asked, only to find out I didn't understand the question in the first place.  I also think Github has been kind of confusing in troubleshooting errors and Im not always finding the information I need to troubleshoot whenever I run into a problem.
column17: I think I really need to maybe work on preparations before I try to do learning target checks or projects because sometimes I think the learning targets and projects require more knowledge or practice before being able to answer the questions which I don't feel I have.  I often find that im spending so much time searching for code that works to answer the question that I loose track of time and can't meet the deadline of the learning target check.  I think its become really frustrating for me as a learner to try to meet the pace but I haven't quite given up yet.
column18: what kind of questions do you like us asking you as the instructor? This is something that is really hard for me to gauge I think because I know I should know the coding better, but even if I understand the problem Im not comfortable enough with the coding to make sure I have done it right to answer the question. So I often don't know if the question im asking can be found in the resources we are already given or if I need to do more searching.  Most often I feel I know what needs to be done to tidy the data but I need to figure out whats the best process out of what we have learned to do it, and Im not sure I have done a good job of it as yet.

column15: I think the Primers and the in-class activities have significantly helped my understanding.
column16: The Project are quite tough. At least the one I am currently working on. I feel that the questions are too broad. I find myself spending hours trying to even figure out how I am supposed to be responding or thinking of what the professor would be looking for in the output.
column17: I really don't have an answer for this. I feel like I am doing the best of abilities to understand and learn RStudio and R code including reading all information provided, completing activities, completing learning target checks, and looking online for when I am stumped.

column15: Effective explanation by professor.
column16: nothing
column17: I just listen to classes and practice from the given assignments mostly. Apart from that, i also search information form online to learn extra concepts.

column15: The relevance of the material is very high. I am able to immediately apply the things we are learning, which is very exciting.
column16: I would change the structure so that one day each week would be the entire class together, with the professor leading class. Then use the other day for group activities.
column17: More learning journals. I have not been very good about keeping up with them. I need to get on a schedule to do them more frequently.

column15: The best aspect about this course is that the overarching topics of the activities and projects are pretty intriguing. With things like the gender pay gap and college major earnings, I am actually motivated to create my own visualizations and explore the data myself.
column16:
I think that more examples of troubleshooting that includes a mock process of googling and looking through R4DS would be helpful. 
Another thing that would be helpful is recorded tutorial videos
column17: Watch more YouTube videos on R and play around with data in R in my free time.
column18:
It is hard to pinpoint one thing that I would change, but I think that the course would benefit from more guided activities. The Rstudio primers seem to give me a good understanding when I do the preparations, but once I get into the activities or projects themselves, I have an extremely hard time figuring out what to do. I get that this is what coding always entails (figuring out how to get the desired output), but R seems to be just very hard to learn for someone who is new to it. This course relies on the student to know (and/or figure out) how to teach themselves coding. 
I think another thing that would be helpful are optional recorded lecture videos that would use the functions that we have covered. The teaching in the live sessions are great, but more focused and comprehensive recorded videos would be much better in my opinion. Aside from the Rstudio primers, there is no exposure to the actual process of coding aside from doing that activities and projects. This is good in its own way because I learn how to figure things out myself, but I often feel that there are much better ways of figuring things out than the way I have been doing.

column15: Learning activities, and preparations. Both combined allow the newly learnt information settle in better.
column16: Nothing I can think of so far.
column17: Take more detailed notes

column15: The book readings, primers, and being able to work through the activities with classmates has been the most beneficial to learning the material for me. The readings and primers explain things well and have good examples, and being able to combine our understanding with others in class and ask questions during the activities is helpful.
column16: Keeping up with the learning journals can be hard, and sometimes I feel like I get more out of applying what I learned in the projects, learning target checks, and activities than writing the learning journals.
column17: Doing the exercises in the book to practice using what I just read about right away.

column15: The Learning targets help us in learning the course
column16: The learning journals, are too much to work on
column17: Reduce Learning journals.

column15: The class sessions and primers are by far the best aspects because that is where I learn the most about class material.
column16: I would like to do projects in partners, I think the projects are a little difficult and I think doing them with another person would be helpful.
column17: I think reviewing the material a lot more would help me, either in the book or the primers. But also asking more questions as well.

column15: I think the online format is nice for this class because I am able to focus without distractions from other classmate discussions.
column16: More clear and informative instructions in class activities and projects, so I can focus more on R and less on interpreting directions.
column17: I am going to do a better job of learning the preparation material before the class. I think extra review will help me learn it before hand instead of in the class.

column15: Learning the basics of R programming is interesting, I especially enjoyed making scatterplots.
column16: Have more than one class to go over topics, maybe spend at least two or maybe three. Especially with pivot stuff which is more confusing. Post code that is similar to the answers to activities so we have access to information we know is correct.
column17: Get better time management, also self discipline in starting and finishing tasks in one sitting. Also setting time aside on weekends to do work, especially the projects (maybe catch up on things I skimmed over during the week but hopefully not).

column15: I think the R studio e-courses have been particularly helpful
column16: The team aspect
column17: Probably code more outside of classwork

column15: I like that a lot of the assignments are done outside of class time.
column16: I am not looking forward to the group project.
column17: I should start working on assignments earlier.

column15: The organization. Everything is organized so well that it makes everything flow smoothly, especially considering the content is all online.
column16: Only gripe I have is the learning journals if anything and it really isn't even that much of one. I just think that they were a little confusing at first but as we've gone through the course they make more sense to me.
column17: Quit procrastinating. I plan on trying to just set aside some time on specific days where I HAVE to sit down and work on something for the class, whether that be a project, or the reading and preparations. I find myself getting slightly overwhelmed simply due to the fact that I am procrastinating but I believe I can turn it around.

column15: The primers and LTCs

column15: Being able to google most things and eventually find an answer.
column16: Less group work time. One of my group members never speaks and also we can be stuck on something for over 20 minutes without help that it seems like more than 1 group gets stuck on. I think we could be pulled back into the main room and work through it as a class.

column18: For the blackboard site I just wish the weekly content tab was up further. It's really the only one I click on besides the online class through collaborate. Also the begin here tab is confusing to still have since that was the first week of classes.

column15: The preparations are pretty helpful

column16: The group work is good and all, but I don't like that it takes up most of the end of class. I wish we had like 20 minutes after class to ask questions and discuss.

column15: The best aspect has been the organization of the course. The material is already confusing to tackle, but the way everything is organized and the group work as well are really helping make this course less daunting.
